newsitem.title: USA: Fed may conduct US bill pass in late Oct - experts.
newsitem.headline: Fed may conduct US bill pass in late Oct - experts.

text.p: The Federal Reserve may add permanent reserves to the U.S. banking system late in the month or early in November in a bid to meet higher demand for cash ahead of the year-end holidays, Wall Street pundits said.
"We're looking for a bill pass. I think the most likely dates are either October 30th or November 6th," said Dana Saporta, economist at Stone and McCarthy Research Associates.

Historically, the Federal Reserve faces a seasonal add need late in the year. Analysts said, however, they see the Fed entering the market through a single bill pass operation and not several tranches of coupon passes.
"I think that with bills they (Fed officials) still do it the old-fashioned way," said Kevin Flanagan, first-vice president and an economist at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.
"It's likely to be just one go-around type of a thing unlike the coupons which take them a couple of days to accomplish," Flanagan added.

The Fed has bought bills every year in late October or early November for at least the past seven years, analysts said. "That's the history. That's why I'm calling for bills rather than coupons," Saporta said.
